instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Failed PBUS sensor
threads.message:
Mac runs normally and charges battery. PBUS sensor in hardware profile says zero volts. I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q5500</TRANSISTOR> and checked the resistors and cap on the circuit line and everything measures ok. PPBUS without a battery is 8.58 volts. With a battery, it starts at 7.6 with the machine off and the charger plugged in then as it boots it goes up to 8.4 volts. The battery is only at 15%, so my question is once again

1. Does this matter and should I stress over it?
2. Could the sensor be pulled down by a old or shit battery?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Failed PBUS sensor
threads.message: It should certainly not read 0V. Also you replace stuff before measuring? <TRANSISTOR>Q5500</TRANSISTOR> pin 4 is the input and pin 3 the output then a voltage divider and to the SMC. Measure first.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Failed PBUS sensor
threads.message: Ok will measure and see what's up with that one.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Failed PBUS sensor
threads.message: So <TRANSISTOR>Q5500</TRANSISTOR> has 8.58 volts on input but zero volts on output. <SIGNAL>SMC_SENSOR_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> is 3.42 volts. <RESISTOR>R5503</RESISTOR> measures normal but <RESISTOR>R5504</RESISTOR> measures 4.56K not 5.49K. This may be a dumb question but is <RESISTOR>R5504</RESISTOR> bad or could something else be making that measurement low?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Failed PBUS sensor
threads.message: Replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q5500</TRANSISTOR> now power passes through it still fails sensor test. Measured <RESISTOR>R5501</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R5503</RESISTOR>, and <RESISTOR>R5504</RESISTOR> and they all measure correctly now. <RESISTOR>R5504</RESISTOR> is now 5.49K. <CAPACITOR>C5504</CAPACITOR> is not shorted. Does this mean crap under the SMC is failing the sensor test?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Failed PBUS sensor
threads.message: You should have about 4.3V on pin 5 and 8.5V on pin 3, if not, maybe a broken trace or bad resistor between pin 4-<RESISTOR>R5501</RESISTOR>-<RESISTOR>R5502</RESISTOR>-pin 6....

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Failed PBUS sensor
threads.message: what voltage do you have on <SIGNAL>SMC_PBUS_VSENSE</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Failed PBUS sensor
threads.message: 1.44 volts. I'm guessing that's way too low?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Failed PBUS sensor
threads.message: no, in fact is perfectly fine, seems a problem with SMC, any signs of water damage???

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Failed PBUS sensor
threads.message: Yes definitely had water damage at some point. Would this be a dead SMC or maybe just crap under the SMC?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Failed PBUS sensor
threads.message: Also continuity between resistors and <TRANSISTOR>Q5500</TRANSISTOR> so that's good.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Failed PBUS sensor
threads.message:
Apply some flux and heat, most of the time this works....

Yes, if you have 1.4V at <SIGNAL>SMC_PBUS_VSENSE</SIGNAL> <TRANSISTOR>Q5500</TRANSISTOR> is working properly

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Failed PBUS sensor
threads.message: Ok will try that and report back.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Failed PBUS sensor
threads.message: Zero dice. Sensor still fails despite reflow. Would this mean SMC is partially dead or would this be anything else? I'm out of ideas on this one.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Failed PBUS sensor
threads.message: Ok now I feel dumb lmfao. The only thing I didn't try was a different battery. With a FOR SURE known good, it passes the sensor lmaooooo. The battery that was with the machine says condition NORMAL in the OS, but it causes the sensor to fail. All that for a DAMN BATTERY LOL that sucks but mark this as sovled

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Failed PBUS sensor
threads.message: Also learned a partially bad battery will cause VP0R to fail. Learn something new every day! Thank you Duke and apprendiz for the help tho I really appreciate it.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Failed PBUS sensor
threads.message: Only if the battery was completely drained. Let it charge up for a while and try again.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Failed PBUS sensor
threads.message: It was at about 50% when testing so I'm guessing it's toast.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Failed PBUS sensor
threads.message: Tested with the battery still fails sensor. With known good it passes so battery toast. Board fixed tho thank you to all you guys glad this worked out!
